Sure, but that’s attributing causality.
The hypothesis test tells you if there is evidence to reject your null hypothesis, which is a statement about the avg infection rate difference in the population.
So it will tell you that.
But that is not the thing we are actually interested in.
We are actually interested in the transmissability.
So we need to control for everything else.

text:
As a particular example of why looking at those statistics alone will mislead is if you look at the figures for Australia.

Right now there are about 120 active cases in Australia
20 of them are from overseas and are in hotel quarantine.
We can assume those probably are a random scattering of variants.
but the other 100 are an outbreak in Sydney, which can be traced to a single person who had contact with people in quarantine.

So if you look at those statistics it will say that that one variant is much more common — 100 cases vs everything else having only 20 combined.

Further, even if you look at number of cases transmitted it will say similar.
That variant has had 100 people catch it.
the others have had 0.
because they are in quarentine.

Definitely cannot view more infections detected as evidence of transmissibility. Infections are still very low proportion of population, which means very susceptible to founder effects and other random outcomes

I don't know what this means in terms of Bayes or t tests, but I know it is very easy to fool yourself into thinking you see a phenotype when what you're really seeing is random.

As an example, if you model equal proportions of replicators with equal fitness, after usually a few dozens of generations, you only see one type of replicator left. Because at random, one will start to dominate

attachments.title: Birthday problem
attachments.text:
In probability theory, the birthday problem or birthday paradox concerns the probability that, in a set of n randomly chosen people, some pair of them will have the same birthday. By the pigeonhole principle, the probability reaches 100% when the number of people reaches 367 (since there are only 366 possible birthdays, including February 29). However, 99.9% probability is reached with just 70 people, and 50% probability with 23 people. These conclusions are based on the assumption that each day of the year (excluding February 29) is equally probable for a birthday.
Actual birth records show that different numbers of people are born on different days. In this case, it can be shown that the number of people required to reach the 50% threshold is 23 or fewer. For example, if half the people were born on one day and the other half on another day, then any two people would have a 50% chance of sharing a birthday.
It may well seem surprising that a group of just 23 individuals is required to reach a probability of 50% that at least two individuals in the group have the same birthday: this result is perhaps made more plausible by considering that the comparisons of birthday will actually be made between every possible pair of individuals = 23 × 22/2 = 253 comparisons, which is well over half the number of days in a year (183 at most), as opposed to fixing on one individual and comparing their birthday to everyone else's. The birthday problem is not a "paradox" in the literal logical sense of being self-contradictory, but is merely unintuitive at first glance.
Real-world applications for the birthday problem include a cryptographic attack called the birthday attack, which uses this probabilistic model to reduce the complexity of finding a collision for a hash function, as well as calculating the approximate risk of a hash collision existing within the hashes of a given size of population.
The history of the problem is obscure. The result has been attributed to Harold Davenport; however, a version of what is considered today to be the birthday problem was proposed earlier by Richard von Mises.

text:
What <@U6A936746> said - you use hypothesis testing to tell you whether there are more people in south England infected with this variant than in the north. Or more than 4 months ago.

What you can't do is test the hypothesis that the observed differences are due to viral phenotype. Or, it's not that you can't do it, it's that it's much more difficult and your conclusion is going to need to be much more circumspect.

I suspect there's no way to get power given our coverage of viral isolate sequencing. We'd want to be able to find a bunch of places where it was introduced and see if it ends up with the same trajectory
